No pain. No gain.

You will never fully appreciate anything you didn't have to work for. Things that are handed to us or acquired easily hold little to no value in our mind because the lesson we receive is we can get that anytime with no problem. Thus it's of no importance. Things that were only acquired or achieved after great difficulty - whether physical, emotional, or both - we automatically see as being more valuable because we know the effort that was involved first hand. This tends to stick with us much more clearly and longer than the easy things, which in turn teaches us the value of hard work and the kind of payoff that can only be attained in that manner. We will then have “gained” valuable wisdom and insights about ourselves and about life through the “pain” or difficulty we felt.

Give me some motivation!
{/**/}

The physical benefits of sport

Keeping active through physical activity and sport has many benefits for the body. Some of these benefits include increased cardiovascular fitness, bone health, decreased risk of obesity, improved sleep, and better coordination and balance. Reducing the amount of time spent in sedentary activities such as watching TV or playing computer games is also recommended and can be just as important as increasing physical activity. Setting time limits for your kids when it comes to sedentary activities can help with this.

Learning important life skills

Engaging in sport is important for more than just physical fitness. Playing sport often means being part of a team and this allows for building skills in a whole range of areas. As well as learning all of the techniques involved in the sport, children can also develop their life skills. Playing team sports encourages cooperation and sharing, resilience, goal setting and building relationships. Learning to lose is also an important skill that’s often uncovered through playing sport.
